Implicit Decomposition for
Write-Efficient Connectivity Algorithms

Abstract

The future of main memory appears to lie in the direction of new technologies that provide strong capacity-to-performance ratios, but have write operations that are much more expensive than reads in terms of latency, bandwidth, and energy. Motivated by this trend, we propose sequential and parallel algorithms to solve graph connectivity problems using significantly fewer writes than conventional algorithms. Our primary algorithmic tool is the construction of an oâ€‹(n)ğ‘œğ‘›o(n)-sized implicit decomposition of a bounded-degree graph GğºG on nğ‘›n nodes, which combined with read-only access to GğºG enables fast answers to connectivity and biconnectivity queries on GğºG. The construction breaks the linear-write â€œbarrierâ€, resulting in costs that are asymptotically lower than conventional algorithms while adding only a modest cost to querying time. For general non-sparse graphs on mğ‘šm edges, we also provide the first oâ€‹(m)ğ‘œğ‘šo(m) writes and Oâ€‹(m)ğ‘‚ğ‘šO(m) operations parallel algorithms for connectivity and biconnectivity. These algorithms provide insight into how applications can efficiently process computations on large graphs in systems with read-write asymmetry.

1 Introduction

Recent trends in computer memory technologies suggest wide adoption of memory systems in which reading from memory is significantly cheaper than writing to it, especially with regards to energy. The reason for this asymmetry, roughly speaking, is that writing to memory requires a change to the state of the material, while reading only requires detecting the current state.111See AppendixÂ A for some technical details of the new memories. This trend poses the interesting question of how to design algorithms that are more efficient in the number of writes than in the number of reads. To this end recent works have studied models that account for asymmetric read-write costs and have analyzed a variety of algorithms in these modelsÂ [8, 9, 12, 13, 15, 17, 24, 25, 31, 38, 46, 47].

Some of this work has shown an inherent tradeoff between reads and writes. For example, Blelloch et al.Â [13] show that for computations on certain DAGs, any reduction in writes requires an increase in reads. For FFTs and sorting networks, for example, the increase in reads is exponential with respect to the decrease in writes. Intuitively, the tradeoff is because reducing writes restricts the ability to save partial results needed in multiple places, and hence requires repeating certain computations. This is reminiscent of well-studied time-space tradeoffsÂ [29]â€”but not the same, because time-space models still allow an arbitrary number of writes to the limited space, with each write costing the same as a read.

In this paper we are interested in graph connectivity problems, and in particular whether it is possible to build an â€œoracleâ€ using a sublinear number of writes that supports fast queries, along with any read-write tradeoffs this entails. We consider undirected connectivity (connected components, spanning forests) and biconnectivity (biconnected components, articulation points, and related 1-edge-connectivity) problems. We do not consider the cost of initially storing the graph in memory, but note that there are many scenarios in which the graph is either represented implicitly, e.g., the Swendsen-Wang algorithmÂ [44], or for which the graph is sampled and used multiple times, e.g., edges selected based on different Boolean hash functions or based on properties (timestamp, weight, relationship, etc.) associated with the edge.

Our results show that if a graph with nğ‘›n vertices and mğ‘šm edges is sufficiently dense, a sublinear number of writes (oâ€‹(m)ğ‘œğ‘šo(m)) can be achieved without asymptotically increasing the number of reads (no tradeoff is required). For bounded-degree graphs, on the other hand, our algorithm achieving a sublinear number of writes (oâ€‹(n)ğ‘œğ‘›o(n)) involves a linear tradeoff between reads and writes. The main technical contribution is a new implicit decomposition of a graph that allows writing out information only for a suitably small sample of the vertices. We use two models to account for the read-write asymmetry: (i) the Asymmetric RAM modelÂ [13], in which writes to the asymmetric memory cost Ï‰â‰«1much-greater-thanğœ”1\omega\gg 1 and all other operations are unit cost; and (ii) its parallel variant, the Asymmetric NP modelÂ [9]. Both models have a small symmetric memory (a cache) that can be used to help minimize the number of writes to the large asymmetric memory.

TableÂ 1 summarizes our main results for these models, showing asymptotic improvements in construction costs over all prior work (sequential or parallel) for these well-studied connectivity problems.

While standard sequential BFS- or DFS-based graph connectivity algorithms require only Oâ€‹(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n) writes, and hence already achieve this bound, the parallel setting is more challenging. Existing linear-work parallel connectivity algorithms perform Î˜â€‹(m)Î˜ğ‘š\Theta(m) writesÂ [20, 26, 27, 28, 39, 40, 43], and hence are actually Î˜â€‹(Ï‰â€‹m)Î˜ğœ”ğ‘š\Theta(\omega m) work in the asymmetric memory setting. We show how the algorithm of Shun et al.Â [43] can be adapted to use only Oâ€‹(m/Ï‰+n)ğ‘‚ğ‘šğœ”ğ‘›O(m/\omega+n) writes (and Oâ€‹(m)ğ‘‚ğ‘šO(m) other operations), by avoiding repeated graph contractions and using a recent write-efficient BFSÂ [9], yielding the first Oâ€‹(m+Ï‰â€‹n)ğ‘‚ğ‘šğœ”ğ‘›O(m+\omega{}n) expected work, low-0pt parallel algorithm for connectivity in the asymmetric setting. (By low 0pt we mean 0pt polynomial in Ï‰â€‹logâ¡nğœ”ğ‘›\omega\log n.)

For biconnectivity, the standard output is an array of size mğ‘šm indicating to which biconnected component each edge belongsÂ [21, 32]. Producing this output requires at least mğ‘šm writes, and as a result, the sequential time (and parallel work) ends up being Î˜â€‹(Ï‰â€‹m)Î˜ğœ”ğ‘š\Theta(\omega m) in the asymmetric memory setting. We present an equally effective representation of the output, which we call the BC labeling, which has size only Oâ€‹(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n). This leads to a sequential biconnectivity algorithm that constructs the oracle in only Oâ€‹(m+Ï‰â€‹n)ğ‘‚ğ‘šğœ”ğ‘›O(m+\omega n) time in the asymmetric setting. Moreover, we show how to leverage our new parallel connectivity algorithm to compute the BC labeling in Oâ€‹(m/Ï‰+n)ğ‘‚ğ‘šğœ”ğ‘›O(m/\omega+n) writes, yielding the first Oâ€‹(m+Ï‰â€‹n)ğ‘‚ğ‘šğœ”ğ‘›O(m+\omega{}n) work parallel algorithm for biconnectivity in the asymmetric memory setting. Algorithms with oâ€‹(n)ğ‘œğ‘›o(n) writes for sparse graphs. For sparse graphs, the work of our connectivity and biconnectivity algorithms is dominated by the Î©â€‹(n)Î©ğ‘›\Omega(n) writes they perform. This led us to explore the following fundamental question: Is it possible to construct, using oâ€‹(n)ono(n) writes to the asymmetric memory, an oracle for graph connectivity (or biconnectivity) that can answer queries in time independent of nnn? Given that the standard output for these problems (even with BC labeling) is Î˜â€‹(n)Î˜ğ‘›\Theta(n) size even for bounded-degree graphs, one might conjecture that Î©â€‹(n)Î©ğ‘›\Omega(n) writes are required. Our main contribution is a (perhaps surprising) affirmative answer to the above question for both the connectivity and biconnectivity problems.

The key technical contribution behind our breaking of the Î©â€‹(n)Î©ğ‘›\Omega(n)-write â€œbarrierâ€ is the definition and use of an implicit kkk-decomposition of a graph. Informally, a kğ‘˜k-decomposition of a graph GğºG is comprised of a subset Sğ‘†S of the vertices, called centers, and a mapping Ïâ€‹(â‹…)ğœŒâ‹…\rho(\cdot) that partitions the vertices among the centers, such that (i) |S|=Oâ€‹(n/k)ğ‘†ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘˜|S|=O(n/k), (ii) the number of vertices in each partition is at most kğ‘˜k, and (iii) for each center, the induced subgraph on its vertices is connected. However, explicitly storing the center associated with each vertex would require Î©â€‹(n)Î©ğ‘›\Omega(n) writes. Instead, an implicit kğ‘˜k-decomposition defines the mapping implicitly in terms of a procedure that is given only GğºG and Sğ‘†S (and a 1-bit labeling on Sğ‘†S).

With the new concept of implicit kğ‘˜k-decomposition, we present three algorithmic subroutines which together construct connectivity and biconnectivity oracles with Oâ€‹(m/Ï‰)ğ‘‚ğ‘šğœ”O(m/\sqrt{\omega}) writes, which is oâ€‹(n)ğ‘œğ‘›o(n) when mâˆˆoâ€‹(Ï‰â€‹n)ğ‘šğ‘œğœ”ğ‘›m\in o(\sqrt{\omega}n). For clarity of presentation, we begin by assuming the input graph has bounded degree. SectionÂ 6 discusses how to relax this constraint.

We first present an algorithm to compute an implicit kğ‘˜k-decomposition that can be constructed in only Oâ€‹(n/k)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘˜O(n/k) writes, Oâ€‹(kâ€‹n)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜ğ‘›O(kn) reads, and low 0pt, and can compute Ïâ€‹(v)ğœŒğ‘£\rho(v) in only Oâ€‹(k)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜O(k) expected reads and no asymmetric memory writes. The intuition behind our construction is first to pick a random subset of the vertices and then map each unpicked vertex to the closest center by performing a BFS on the graph GğºG. Unfortunately, this does not satisfy the constraint on partition size, so a more sophisticated approach is needed. The unique challenge that arises again and again in the asymmetric context is that the sublinear limitation on the number of writes rules out the approaches used by prior work.

We then show how the implicit kğ‘˜k-decomposition can be used to solve graph connectivity and biconnectivity. We define the concept of a clusters graph, which contains vertices each representing a cluster and edges between clusters. The key idea is that after precomputing on the clusters graph and storing a constant amount of information about connectivity and biconnectivity on each vertex (corresponding to a cluster in the original graph), a connectivity or biconnectivity query can be answered by only looking at the local structure and preprocessed information on a constant number of clusters. This is straightforward for connectivity queries because we need only compare the labels of the clusters that contains the respective query points. However, this becomes much more challenging in graph biconnectivity since the correspondence between the clusters and biconnected components is non-trivial: a cluster may contain the vertices in many biconnected components while the vertices in a certain biconnected component can belong to different clusters. Therefore, biconnectivity queries require considerable subtleties in the design, to store the appropriate information on the clusters graph that enables each query to access only a constant number of clusters (at most 3). More specifically, we define the concept of the local graph of each cluster (it maintains the relationship of biconnectivity of this cluster and its neighbor clusters and can be computed with the cost proportional to the size of this cluster), such that the biconnectivity queries discussed in SectionÂ 5 can be answered by looking up a constant number of local graphs and the information stored in the clusters graph.

Our sequential algorithms have significant algorithmic merits on their own, but we also show that all the algorithms can be made to run in parallel with low 0pt. We show:

Theorem 1.2.

Graph connectivity and biconnectivity oracles can be constructed in Oâ€‹(m/Ï‰)ğ‘‚ğ‘šğœ”O(m/\sqrt{\omega}) expected writes and Oâ€‹(mâ€‹Ï‰)ğ‘‚ğ‘šğœ”O(m\sqrt{\omega}) expected time (parallel work) on the Asymmetric RAM model (Asymmetric NP model, respectively). The 0pt on the Asymmetric NP is Oâ€‹(Ï‰3/2â€‹log3â¡n)ğ‘‚superscriptğœ”32superscript3ğ‘›O(\omega^{3/2}\log^{3}n) whp. Each connectivity query can be answered in Oâ€‹(Ï‰1/2)ğ‘‚superscriptğœ”12O(\omega^{1/2}) expected time (work) (Oâ€‹(Ï‰â€‹log1/2â¡n)ğ‘‚ğœ”superscript12ğ‘›O(\omega{}^{1/2}\log n) whp) and each biconnectivity query in Oâ€‹(Ï‰)ğ‘‚ğœ”O(\omega) expected time (work) (Oâ€‹(Ï‰â€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğœ”ğ‘›O(\omega{}\log n) whp). The symmetric memory is Oâ€‹(Ï‰â€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğœ”ğ‘›O(\omega\log n) words.

2 Preliminaries and Related Work

Let G=(V,E)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸G=(V,E) be an undirected, unweighted graph with n=|V|ğ‘›ğ‘‰n=|V| vertices and m=|E|ğ‘šğ¸m=|E| edges. GğºG can contain self-loops and parallel (duplicate) edges, and is not necessarily connected. We assume a global ordering of the vertices to break ties when necessary. If the degree of every vertex is bounded by a constant, we say the graph is bounded-degree. We use standard definitions of spanning tree, spanning forest, connected component, biconnected component, articulation points, bridge, and kğ‘˜k-edge-connectivity on a graph, and lowest-common-ancestor (LCA) query on a tree (as summarized in AppendixÂ B). Let [n]={1,2,â‹¯,n}delimited-[]ğ‘›12â‹¯ğ‘›[n]=\{1,2,\cdots,n\} where nğ‘›n is a positive integer.

Computation models. Sequential algorithms are analyzed using the Asymmetric RAM modelÂ [13], comprised of an infinitely large asymmetric memory and a small symmetric memory. The cost of writing to the large memory is Ï‰ğœ”\omega, and all other operations have unit cost. This models practical settings in which there is a small amount of standard symmetric memory (e.g., a cache) in addition to the asymmetric memory.

For parallel algorithms, we use the Asymmetric Nested-ParallelÂ (NP) modelÂ [9], which is designed to characterize both parallelism and memory read-write asymmetry. In the model, a computation is represented as a (dynamically unfolding) directed acyclic graph (DAG) of tasks that begins and ends with a single task called the root. A task consists of a sequence of instructions that must be executed in order. Tasks can also call the Fork instruction, which creates child tasks that can be run in parallel with each other. The memory in the Asymmetric NPÂ Model consists of (i) an infinitely large asymmetric memory accessible to all tasks and (ii) a small task-specific symmetric memory accessible only to a task and its children. The cost of writing to large memory is Ï‰ğœ”\omega, and all other operations have unit cost. The work Wğ‘ŠW of a computation is the sum of the costs of the operations in its DAG and the 0pt Dğ·D is the cost of the DAGâ€™s most expensive path. Under mild assumptions, Ben-David et al.Â [9] showed that a work-stealing scheduler can execute an algorithm whose Asymmetric NP complexity is work Wğ‘ŠW and 0pt Dğ·D in Oâ€‹(W/P+Ï‰â€‹D)ğ‘‚ğ‘Šğ‘ƒğœ”ğ·O(W/P+\omega D) expected time on Pğ‘ƒP processors.

In both models, the number of writes refers only to the writes to the asymmetric memory, ignoring any writes to symmetric memory. All reads and writes are to words of size Î˜â€‹(logâ¡n)Î˜ğ‘›\Theta(\log n) for input size nğ‘›n. The size of the symmetric memory is measured in words.

Related Work. Read-write asymmetries have been studied in the context of NAND Flash chipsÂ [8, 24, 25, 38], focusing on how to balance the writes across the chip to avoid uneven wear-out of locations. Targeting instead the new memory technologies, read-write asymmetries have been an active area of research in the systems/database/architecture communities (e.g., [3, 7, 17, 18, 19, 34, 37, 46, 47, 48, 50, 51, 52, 53]). In the algorithms community, Blelloch et al.Â [12] defined several sequential and parallel computation models that take asymmetric read-write costs into account, and analyzed and designed sorting algorithms under these models. Their follow-up paperÂ [13] presented sequential algorithms for various problems that do better than their classic counterparts under asymmetric read-write costs, as well as several lower bounds. Carson et al.Â [15] presented write-efficient sequential algorithms for a similar model, as well as write-efficient parallel algorithms (and lower bounds) on a distributed memory model with asymmetric read-write costs, focusing on linear algebra problems and direct N-body methods. Ben-David et al.Â [9] proposed a nested-parallel model with asymmetric read-write costs and presented write-efficient, work-efficient, low 0pt (span) parallel algorithms for reduce, list contraction, tree contraction, breadth-first search, ordered filter, and planar convex hull, as well as a write-efficient, low-0pt minimum spanning tree algorithm that is nearly work-efficient. Jacob and SitchinavaÂ [31] showed lower bounds for an asymmetric external memory model. In each of these models, there is a small amount of symmetric memory that can be used to help minimize the number of writes to the large asymmetric memory.

Although graph decompositions with various properties have been shown to be quite useful in a large variety of applications (e.g., [1, 4, 5, 6, 14, 35, 36]), to our knowledge none of the prior algorithms provide the necessary conditions for processing graphs with a sublinear number of writes in order to answer connectivity/biconnectivity queries (targeting instead other decomposition properties that are unnecessary in our setting, such as few edges between clusters). For example, Miller et al.â€™sÂ [36] parallel low-diameter decomposition algorithm requires at least Î©â€‹(n)Î©ğ‘›\Omega(n) writes (even if a write-efficient BFSÂ [9] is used), and provides no guarantees on the partition sizes. Similarly, algorithms for size-balanced graph partitioning (e.g., [2]) require Î©â€‹(n)Î©ğ‘›\Omega(n) writes. Our implicit kğ‘˜k-decomposition construction is reminiscient of sublinear time algorithms for estimating the number of connected componentsÂ [10, 16] in its use of BFS from a sample of the vertices. However, their BFS is used for a completely different purpose (approximate counting of 1/nu1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘¢1/n_{u}, the inverse of the size of the connected component containing a sampled node uğ‘¢u), does not provide a partitioning of the nodes into clusters (two BFS from different nodes can overlap), and cannot be used for connectivity or biconnectivity queries (two BFS from the same connected component may be truncated before intersecting).

3 Implicit Decomposition

In this paper we introduce the concept of an implicit decomposition. The idea is to partition a graph into connected clusters such that all we need to store to represent the cluster is one representative, which we call the center of the cluster, and some small amount of information on that center (1 bit in our case). The goal is to quickly answer queries on the cluster. The queries we consider are: given a vertex find its center, and given a center find all its vertices. To reduce the amount of symmetric-memory needed, we need all clusters to be roughly the same size. We start with some definitions, which consider only undirected graphs.

For graph G=(V,E)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸G=(V,E) we refer to the subgraph induced by a subset of vertices as a cluster. A decomposition of a connected graph G=(V,E)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸G=(V,E) is a vertex subset SâŠ‚Vğ‘†ğ‘‰S\subset V, called centers, and a function Ïâ€‹(v):Vâ†’S:ğœŒğ‘£â†’ğ‘‰ğ‘†\rho(v):V\to S, such that the cluster Câ€‹(s)={vâˆˆV|Ïâ€‹(v)=s}ğ¶ğ‘ conditional-setğ‘£ğ‘‰ğœŒğ‘£ğ‘ C(s)=\{v\in V~{}|~{}\rho(v)=s\} for each center sâˆˆSğ‘ ğ‘†s\in S is connected. A decomposition is a k-decomposition if the size of each cluster is upper bounded by kğ‘˜k, and |S|=Oâ€‹(n/k)ğ‘†ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘˜|S|=O(n/k) (i.e. all clusters are about the same size). We are often interested in the graph induced by the decomposition, and in particular:

Definition 1 (clusters graph).

Given the decomposition (S,Ï)ğ‘†ğœŒ(S,\rho) of a graph G=(V,E)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸G=(V,E), the clusters graph is the multigraph Gâ€²=(S,âŸ¨{Ï(u),Ï(v)}:{u,v}âˆˆE,Ï(u)â‰ Ï(v)âŸ©)G^{\prime}=(S,\langle\ \{\rho(u),\rho(v)\}:\{u,v\}\in E,\rho(u)\neq\rho(v)\ \rangle\ ).

Definition 2 (implicit decomposition).

An implicit decomposition of a connected graph G=(V,E)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸G=(V,E) is a decomposition (S,Ï,â„“)ğ‘†ğœŒâ„“(S,\rho,\ell) such that Ïâ€‹(â‹…)ğœŒâ‹…\rho(\cdot) is defined implicitly in terms of an algorithm given only GğºG, Sğ‘†S, and a (short) labeling â„“â€‹(s)â„“ğ‘ \ell(s) on sâˆˆSğ‘ ğ‘†s\in S.

Note that this theorem indicates a linear tradeoff of reads (operations) and writes for the construction that is controlled by kğ‘˜k.

At a high level, the construction algorithm works by identifying a subset of centers such that every vertex can quickly find its nearest center without having to keep a pointer to it (which would require too many writes). It first selects a random subset of the vertices where each vertex is selected with probability 1/k1ğ‘˜1/k. We call these the primary centers and denote them as S0subscriptğ‘†0S_{0}. All other vertices are then assigned to the nearest such center. Unfortunately, a cluster defined in this way can be significantly larger than kğ‘˜k (super polynomial in kğ‘˜k). To handle this, the algorithm identifies an additional Oâ€‹(n/k)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘˜O(n/k) secondary centers, S1subscriptğ‘†1S_{1}. Every vertex vğ‘£v is associated with a primary center Ï0â€‹(v)âˆˆS0subscriptğœŒ0ğ‘£subscriptğ‘†0\rho_{0}(v)\in S_{0}, and an actual center Ïâ€‹(v)âˆˆS=S0âˆªS1ğœŒğ‘£ğ‘†subscriptğ‘†0subscriptğ‘†1\rho(v)\in S=S_{0}\cup S_{1}. The only values the the algorithm stores are the set Sğ‘†S and the bits â„“â€‹(s),sâˆˆSâ„“ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘†\ell(s),s\in S indicating whether it is primary or secondary.

In our construction it is important to break ties among equal-length paths in a consistent way, such that subpaths of a shortest path are themselves a unique shortest path. For this purpose we assume the vertices have a total ordering (and comparing two vertices takes constant time). Among two equal hop-length paths from a vertex uğ‘¢u, consider the first vertex where the paths diverge. We say that the path with the higher priority vertex at that position is shorter. By our definition all subpaths of a shortest path are also unique shortest paths for a fixed vertex ordering. Lemma 3.2.

Parallelizing the decomposition. To parallelize the decomposition in AlgorithmÂ 1, we make one small change; in addition to adding the secondary cluster uğ‘¢u at each recursive call to SecondaryCenters, we add all children of vğ‘£v. This guarantees that the height of the tree decreases by at least one on each recursive call, and only increases the number of writes by a constant factor. This gives the following lemma.

Lemma 3.7.

AlgorithmÂ 1 runs in depth Oâ€‹((kâ€‹logâ¡n)â€‹(k2â€‹logâ¡n+Ï‰))ğ‘‚ğ‘˜ğ‘›superscriptğ‘˜2ğ‘›ğœ”O((k\log n)(k^{2}\log n+\omega)) whp on the Asymmetric NP.

Proof.

Certainly selecting the set S0subscriptğ‘†0S_{0} can be done in parallel. Furthermore the calls to SecondaryCenters on line 4 can be made recursively in parallel. The depth will be proportional to the depth to each call to SecondaryCenters (not including recursive calls) multiplied by the depth of the recursion. To bound the depth, in the parallel version we also mark the children of the root as secondary centers, which does not increase the number of secondary centers asymptotically (due to the bounded-degree assumption). In this way one is removed from the height of the tree on each recursive call. The depth of the recursion is at most the depth of the tree associated with the primary center Ï0â€‹(v)subscriptğœŒ0ğ‘£\rho_{0}(v). This is bounded by Oâ€‹(kâ€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜ğ‘›O(k\log n) whp since by LemmaÂ 3.2 every vertex finds its primary center within Oâ€‹(kâ€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜ğ‘›O(k\log n) steps whp. The depth of SecondaryCenters (without recursion) is just the number of operations (Oâ€‹(k2â€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2ğ‘›O(k^{2}\log n) whp) plus the depth of the one write of uğ‘¢u (which costs Ï‰ğœ”\omega). Extension to unconnected graphs. Note that once a connected component contains at least one primary center, the definition and TheoremÂ 3.1 hold. However, it is possible that in a small component, the search of Ïâ€‹(â‹…)ğœŒâ‹…\rho(\cdot) exhausts all connected vertices without finding any primary centers (vertices in the initial sample, S0subscriptğ‘†0S_{0}). In this case, we check whether the size of the cluster is at least kğ‘˜k, and if so, we mark as a primary center the vertex that is the smallest according to the total order on vertices. This marks at most n/kğ‘›ğ‘˜n/k primary centers and the rest of the algorithm remains unchanged. This step is added after lineÂ 1 in AlgorithmÂ 1, and requires Oâ€‹(nâ€‹k)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘˜O(nk) work and operations, Oâ€‹(n/k)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘˜O(n/k) writes, and Oâ€‹(k)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜O(k) 0pt. The cost bound therefore is not changed. If the component is smaller than kğ‘˜k, we use the smallest vertex in the component as a center implicitly, but never write it out. The Ïâ€‹(â‹…)ğœŒâ‹…\rho(\cdot) function can easily return this in Oâ€‹(k)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜O(k) operations.

4 Graph Connectivity and Spanning Forest

This section describes parallel write-efficient algorithms for graph connectivity and spanning forest; that is, identifying which vertices belong to each connected component and producing a spanning forest of the graph. These task can be easily accomplished sequentially by performing a breadth-first or depth-first search in the graph with Oâ€‹(m)ğ‘‚ğ‘šO(m) operations and Oâ€‹(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n) writes. While there are several work-efficient parallel algorithms for the problemÂ [43, 20, 26, 40, 39, 28, 27], all of them use Î©â€‹(n+m)Î©ğ‘›ğ‘š\Omega(n+m) writes. This section has two main contributions: (1) SectionÂ 4.2 provides a parallel algorithm using Oâ€‹(n+m/Ï‰)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘šğœ”O(n+m/\omega) writes in expectation, Oâ€‹(nâ€‹Ï‰+m)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğœ”ğ‘šO(n\omega+m) expected work, and Oâ€‹(Ï‰2â€‹log2â¡n)ğ‘‚superscriptğœ”2superscript2ğ‘›O(\omega^{2}\log^{2}n) 0pt with high probability; (2) SectionÂ 4.3 gives an algorithm for constructing a connectivity oracle on constant-degree graphs in Oâ€‹(n/Ï‰)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğœ”O(n/\sqrt{\omega}) expected writes and Oâ€‹(nâ€‹Ï‰)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğœ”O(n\sqrt{\omega}) expected total operations. Our oracle-construction algorithm is parallel, having 0pt Oâ€‹(Ï‰3/2â€‹log3â¡n)ğ‘‚superscriptğœ”32superscript3ğ‘›O(\omega^{3/2}\log^{3}n) whp, but it also represents a contribution as a sequential algorithm.

Our parallel algorithm (SectionÂ 4.2) can be viewed as a write-efficient version of the parallel algorithm due to Shun et al.Â [43]. This algorithm uses a low-diameter decomposition algorithm of Miller et al.Â [36] as a subroutine, which we review and adapt next in SectionÂ 4.1 and AppendixÂ C.

4.1 Low-diameter Decomposition

Here we review the low-diameter decomposition of Miller et al.Â [36]. The so-called â€œ(Î²,d)ğ›½ğ‘‘(\beta,d)-decompositionâ€ is terminology lifted from their paper, and it should not be confused with our implicit kğ‘˜k-decompositions. The details of the decomposition subroutine are only important to extract a bound on the number of writes, and it is briefly summarized in AppendixÂ C.

A (Î²,d)ğ›½ğ‘‘(\beta,d)-decomposition of an undirected graph G=(V,E)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸G=(V,E), where 0<Î²<10ğ›½10<\beta<1 and 1â‰¤dâ‰¤n1ğ‘‘ğ‘›1\leq d\leq n, is defined as a partition of Vğ‘‰V into subsets V1,â€¦,Vksubscriptğ‘‰1â€¦subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜V_{1},\ldots,V_{k} such that (1) the shortest path between any two vertices in each Visubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–V_{i} using only vertices in Visubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–V_{i} is at most dğ‘‘d, and (2) the number of edges (u,v)âˆˆEğ‘¢ğ‘£ğ¸(u,v)\in E crossing the partition, i.e., such that uâˆˆViğ‘¢subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–u\in V_{i}, vâˆˆVjğ‘£subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘—v\in V_{j}, and iâ‰ jğ‘–ğ‘—i\neq j, is at most Î²â€‹mğ›½ğ‘š\beta m. Miller et al.Â [36] provide an efficient parallel algorithm for generating a (Î²,Oâ€‹(logâ¡n/Î²))ğ›½ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ›½(\beta,O(\log n/\beta))-decomposition. As described, however, their algorithm performs Î˜â€‹(m)Î˜ğ‘š\Theta(m) writes. The key subroutine of the algorithm, however, is just breadth-first searches (BFSâ€™s). Replacing these BFSâ€™s by write-efficient BFSâ€™sÂ [9] yields the following theorem:

Theorem 4.1.

A (Î²,Oâ€‹(logâ¡n/Î²))ğ›½ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ›½(\beta,O({\log n}/\beta)) decomposition can be generated in Oâ€‹(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n) expected writes, Oâ€‹(m+Ï‰â€‹n)ğ‘‚ğ‘šğœ”ğ‘›O(m+\omega n) expected work, and Oâ€‹(Ï‰â€‹log2â¡n/Î²)ğ‘‚ğœ”superscript2ğ‘›ğ›½O(\omega{\log^{2}n}/\beta) 0ptÂ whp on the Asymmetric NPÂ model.

4.2 Connectivity and Spanning Forest

The parallel connectivity algorithm ofÂ [43] applies the low-diameter decomposition recursively with Î²ğ›½\beta set to a constant less than 111. Each level of recursion contracts a subset of vertices into a single supervertex for the next level. The algorithm terminates when each connected component is reduced to a single supervertex. The stumbling block for write efficiency is this contraction step, which performs writes proportional to the number of remaining edges.

Instead, our write-efficient algorithm applies the low-diameter decomposition just once, but with a much smaller Î²ğ›½\beta, as follows:

  1. 1.

    Perform the low-diameter decomposition with parameter Î²=1/Ï‰ğ›½1ğœ”\beta=1/\omega.

  2. 2.

    Find a spanning tree on each Visubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–V_{i} (in parallel) using write-efficient BFSâ€™s ofÂ [9].

  3. 3.

    Create a contracted graph, where each vertex subset in the decomposition is contracted down to a single vertex. To write down the cross-subset edges in a compacted array, employ the write-efficient filter ofÂ [9].

  4. 4.

    Run any parallel linear-work spanning forest algorithm on the contracted graph, e.g., the algorithm fromÂ [20] with Oâ€‹(Ï‰â€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğœ”ğ‘›O(\omega\log n) 0pt.

Combining the spanning forest edges across subsets (produced in Step 4) with the spanning tree edges (produced in Step 2) gives a spanning forest on the original graph. Adding the bounds for each step together yields the following theorem. Again only Oâ€‹(1)ğ‘‚1O(1) symmetric memory is required per task.

Theorem 4.2.

For any choice of 0<Î²<10ğ›½10<\beta<1, connectivity and spanning forest can be solved in Oâ€‹(n+Î²â€‹m)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ›½ğ‘šO(n+\beta m) expected writes, Oâ€‹(Ï‰â€‹n+Î²â€‹Ï‰â€‹m+m)ğ‘‚ğœ”ğ‘›ğ›½ğœ”ğ‘šğ‘šO(\omega n+\beta\omega m+m) expected work, and Oâ€‹(Ï‰â€‹log2â¡n/Î²)ğ‘‚ğœ”superscript2ğ‘›ğ›½O(\omega\log^{2}n/\beta) 0pt whp on the Asymmetric NP model. For Î²=1/Ï‰ğ›½1ğœ”\beta=1/\omega, these bounds reduce to Oâ€‹(n+m/Ï‰)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘šğœ”O(n+m/\omega) expected writes, Oâ€‹(m+Ï‰â€‹n)ğ‘‚ğ‘šğœ”ğ‘›O(m+\omega n) expected work and Oâ€‹(Ï‰2â€‹log2â¡n)ğ‘‚superscriptğœ”2superscript2ğ‘›O(\omega^{2}\log^{2}n) 0pt whp.

Proof.

StepÂ 1 has performance bounds given by TheoremÂ 4.1, and the expected number of edges remaining in the contracted graph is at most Î²â€‹mğ›½ğ‘š\beta m. StepÂ 2 performs BFSâ€™s on disjoint subgraphs, so summing across subsets yields Oâ€‹(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n) expected writes and Oâ€‹(m+nâ€‹Ï‰)ğ‘‚ğ‘šğ‘›ğœ”O(m+n\omega) expected work. Since each tree has low diameter ğ’Ÿ=Oâ€‹(logâ¡n/Î²)ğ’Ÿğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ›½{\cal D}=O(\log n/\beta), the BFSâ€™s have 0pt Oâ€‹(Ï‰â€‹ğ’Ÿâ€‹logâ¡n)=Oâ€‹(Ï‰â€‹log2â¡n/Î²)ğ‘‚ğœ”ğ’Ÿğ‘›ğ‘‚ğœ”superscript2ğ‘›ğ›½O(\omega{\cal D}\log n)=O(\omega\log^{2}n/\beta) whpÂ [9]. StepÂ 3 is dominated by the filter, which has a number of writes proportional to the output size of Oâ€‹(Î²â€‹m)ğ‘‚ğ›½ğ‘šO(\beta m), for Oâ€‹(m+Î²â€‹Ï‰â€‹m)ğ‘‚ğ‘šğ›½ğœ”ğ‘šO(m+\beta\omega m) work. The 0pt is Oâ€‹(Ï‰â€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğœ”ğ‘›O(\omega\log n)Â [9]. Finally, the algorithm used in StepÂ 4 is not write-efficient, but the size of the graph is Oâ€‹(n+Î²â€‹m)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ›½ğ‘šO(n+\beta m), giving that many writes and Oâ€‹(Ï‰â€‹(n+mâ€‹Î²))ğ‘‚ğœ”ğ‘›ğ‘šğ›½O(\omega(n+m\beta)) work. Adding these bounds together yields the theorem. âˆ

4.3 Connectivity Oracle in Sublinear Writes

A connectivity oracle supports queries that take as input a vertex and return the label (component ID) of the vertex. This allows one to determine whether two vertices belong in the same component. The algorithm is parameterized by a value kğ‘˜k, to be chosen later. We assume throughout that the symmetric memory per task is Î©â€‹(kâ€‹logâ¡n)Î©ğ‘˜ğ‘›\Omega(k\log n) words and that the graph has bounded degree.

We begin with an outline of the algorithm. The goal is to produce an oracle that can answer for any vertex which component it belongs to in Oâ€‹(k)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜O(k) work. To build the oracle, we would like to run the connectivity algorithm on the clusters graph produced by an implicit kğ‘˜k-decomposition. The result would be that all center vertices in the same component be labeled with the same identifier. Answering a query then amounts to outputting the component ID of the center it maps to, which can be queried in Oâ€‹(k)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜O(k) expected work and Oâ€‹(kâ€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜ğ‘›O(k\log n) work whp according to LemmaÂ 3.2.

The main challenge in implementing this strategy is that we cannot afford to write out the edges of the clusters graphÂ (as there could be too many edges). Instead, we treat the implicit kğ‘˜k-decomposition as an implicit representation of the clusters graph. Given an implicit representation, our connected components algorithm is the following:

  1. 1.

    Find a kğ‘˜k-implicit decomposition of the graph.

  2. 2.

    Run the write-efficient connectivity algorithm from SectionÂ 4.2 with Î²=1/kğ›½1ğ‘˜\beta=1/k, treating the kğ‘˜k-decomposition as an implicit representation of the clusters graph, i.e., querying edges as needed.

As used in the connectivity algorithm, our implicit representation need only be able to list the edges adjacent to a center vertex xğ‘¥x in the clusters graph. To do so, start at xğ‘¥x, and explore outwards (e.g., with BFS), keeping all vertices and edges encountered so far in symmetric memory. For each frontier vertex vğ‘£v, query its center (as in LemmaÂ 3.5) â€” if Ïâ€‹(v)=xğœŒğ‘£ğ‘¥\rho(v)=x, then vğ‘£vâ€™s unexplored neighbors are added to the next frontier; otherwise (if Ïâ€‹(v)â‰ xğœŒğ‘£ğ‘¥\rho(v)\neq x) the edge (x,Ïâ€‹(v))ğ‘¥ğœŒğ‘£(x,\rho(v)) is in the clusters graph, so add it to the output list.

Lemma 4.3.

Assuming a symmetric memory of size Î©â€‹(kâ€‹logâ¡n)Î©ğ‘˜ğ‘›\Omega(k\log n), the centers neighboring each center in the clusters graph can be listed in no writes and work, 0pt, and operations all Oâ€‹(k2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2O(k^{2}) in expectation or Oâ€‹(k2â€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2ğ‘›O(k^{2}\log n) whp.

Proof.

Listing all the vertices in the cluster takes expected work Oâ€‹(k2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2O(k^{2}) according to LemmaÂ 3.5, or Oâ€‹(k2â€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2ğ‘›O(k^{2}\log n) whp. The number of vertices in the cluster is Oâ€‹(k)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜O(k), so they can all fit in symmetric memory. Moreover, since each vertex in the cluster has Oâ€‹(1)ğ‘‚1O(1) neighbors, the total number of explored vertices in neighboring clusters is Oâ€‹(k)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜O(k), all of which can fit in symmetric memory. Each of these vertices is queried with a cost of Oâ€‹(k)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜O(k) operations in expectation and Oâ€‹(kâ€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜ğ‘›O(k\log n) whp given the specified symmetric memory (LemmaÂ 3.2). âˆ

Note that a consequence of the implicit representation is that listing neighbors is more expensive, and thus the number of operations performed by a BFS increases, affecting both the work and the 0pt. The implicit representation is only necessary while operating on the original clusters graph, i.e., while finding the low-diameter decomposition and spanning trees of each of those vertex subsets; the contracted graph can be built explicitly as before. The best choice of kğ‘˜k is k=Ï‰ğ‘˜ğœ”k=\sqrt{\omega}, giving us the following theorem.

Theorem 4.4.

A connectivity oracle that answers queries in Oâ€‹(Ï‰)ğ‘‚ğœ”O(\sqrt{\omega}) expected work and Oâ€‹(Ï‰â€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğœ”ğ‘›O(\sqrt{\omega}\log n) work whp can be constructed in Oâ€‹(n/Ï‰)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğœ”O(n/\sqrt{\omega}) expected writes, Oâ€‹(Ï‰â€‹n)ğ‘‚ğœ”ğ‘›O(\sqrt{\omega}n) expected work, and Oâ€‹(Ï‰3/2â€‹log3â¡n)ğ‘‚superscriptğœ”32superscript3ğ‘›O(\omega^{3/2}\log^{3}n) 0pt whp on the Asymmetric NPÂ model, assuming a symmetric memory of size Î©â€‹(Ï‰â€‹logâ¡n)Î©ğœ”ğ‘›\Omega(\sqrt{\omega}\log n).

Proof.

The kğ‘˜k-implicit decomposition can be found in Oâ€‹(n/k)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘˜O(n/k) writes, Oâ€‹(kâ€‹n+Ï‰â€‹n/k)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜ğ‘›ğœ”ğ‘›ğ‘˜O(kn+\omega n/k) work, and Oâ€‹(kâ€‹logâ¡nâ€‹(k2â€‹logâ¡n+Ï‰))ğ‘‚ğ‘˜ğ‘›superscriptğ‘˜2ğ‘›ğœ”O(k\log n(k^{2}\log n+\omega)) 0pt by LemmasÂ 3.6 andÂ 3.7. For k=Ï‰ğ‘˜ğœ”k=\sqrt{\omega}, these bounds reduce to Oâ€‹(n/Ï‰)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğœ”O(n/\sqrt{\omega}) writes, Oâ€‹(Ï‰â€‹n)ğ‘‚ğœ”ğ‘›O(\sqrt{\omega}n) work, and Oâ€‹(Ï‰3/2â€‹log3â¡n)ğ‘‚superscriptğœ”32superscript3ğ‘›O(\omega^{3/2}\log^{3}n) 0pt.

If we had an explicit representation of the clusters graph with nâ€²=Oâ€‹(n/k)superscriptğ‘›â€²ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘˜n^{\prime}=O(n/k) vertices and mâ€²=Oâ€‹(m)=Oâ€‹(n)superscriptğ‘šâ€²ğ‘‚ğ‘šğ‘‚ğ‘›m^{\prime}=O(m)=O(n) edges, the connectivity algorithm would have Oâ€‹(nâ€²+mâ€²/k)=Oâ€‹(n/k)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›â€²superscriptğ‘šâ€²ğ‘˜ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘˜O(n^{\prime}+m^{\prime}/k)=O(n/k) expected writes, Oâ€‹(Ï‰â€‹nâ€²+Ï‰â€‹mâ€²/k+mâ€²)=Oâ€‹(Ï‰â€‹n/k+n)ğ‘‚ğœ”superscriptğ‘›â€²ğœ”superscriptğ‘šâ€²ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘šâ€²ğ‘‚ğœ”ğ‘›ğ‘˜ğ‘›O(\omega n^{\prime}+\omega m^{\prime}/k+m^{\prime})=O(\omega n/k+n) expected work, and Oâ€‹(Ï‰â€‹kâ€‹log2â¡n)ğ‘‚ğœ”ğ‘˜superscript2ğ‘›O(\omega k\log^{2}n) 0pt whp (by TheoremÂ 4.2). The fact that the clusters graph is implicit means that the BFS needs to perform Oâ€‹(k2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2O(k^{2}) additional work (but not writes) per node in the clusters graph, giving expected work Oâ€‹(Ï‰â€‹n/k+n+k2â€‹nâ€²)=Oâ€‹(Ï‰â€‹n/k+kâ€‹n)ğ‘‚ğœ”ğ‘›ğ‘˜ğ‘›superscriptğ‘˜2superscriptğ‘›â€²ğ‘‚ğœ”ğ‘›ğ‘˜ğ‘˜ğ‘›O(\omega n/k+n+k^{2}n^{\prime})=O(\omega n/k+kn). To get a high probability bound, the 0pt is multiplied by Oâ€‹(k2â€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2ğ‘›O(k^{2}\log n), giving us Oâ€‹(Ï‰â€‹k3â€‹log3â¡n)ğ‘‚ğœ”superscriptğ‘˜3superscript3ğ‘›O(\omega k^{3}\log^{3}n). For k=Ï‰ğ‘˜ğœ”k=\sqrt{\omega}, the work and writes match the theorem statement, but the 0pt is larger than claimed by a Ï‰ğœ”\omega factor.

To remove the extra Ï‰ğœ”\omega factor on the 0pt, we need to look inside the BFS algorithm and its analysisÂ [9]. The Oâ€‹(Ï‰â€‹ğ’Ÿâ€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğœ”ğ’Ÿğ‘›O(\omega{\cal D}\log n) 0pt bound for the BFS, where ğ’Ÿ=Oâ€‹(kâ€‹logâ¡n)ğ’Ÿğ‘‚ğ‘˜ğ‘›{\cal D}=O(k\log n) is the diameter, is dominated by the 0pt of a packing subroutine on vertices of the frontier. This packing subroutine does not look at edges, and is thus not affected by the overhead of finding a vertexâ€™s neighbors in the implicit representation of the clusters graph. Ignoring the packing and just looking at the exploration itself, the 0pt of BFS is Oâ€‹(ğ’Ÿâ€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ’Ÿğ‘›O({\cal D}\log n), which given the implicit representation increases by a Oâ€‹(k2â€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2ğ‘›O(k^{2}\log n) factor. Adding these together, we get 0pt Oâ€‹(Ï‰â€‹kâ€‹log2â¡n+k3â€‹log3â¡n)=Oâ€‹(Ï‰3/2â€‹log3â¡n)ğ‘‚ğœ”ğ‘˜superscript2ğ‘›superscriptğ‘˜3superscript3ğ‘›ğ‘‚superscriptğœ”32superscript3ğ‘›O(\omega k\log^{2}n+k^{3}\log^{3}n)=O(\omega^{3/2}\log^{3}n) for the BFS phases. âˆ

We can also output the spanning forest on the contracted graph in the same bounds, which will be used in the biconnectivity algorithm with sublinear writes.

5 Graph Biconnectivity

In this section we introduce algorithms related to biconnectivity and 1-edge connectivity queries. We first review the classic approach and its output, which requires Oâ€‹(m)ğ‘‚ğ‘šO(m) writes. Then we propose a new BC (biconnected-component) labeling output, which has size Oâ€‹(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n) and can be constructed in Oâ€‹(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n) writes. Queries such as determining bridges, articulation points, and biconnected components can be answered in Oâ€‹(1)ğ‘‚1O(1) operations (and no writes) with the BC labeling. Finally we show how an implicit kğ‘˜k-decomposition (as generated by AlgorithmÂ 1) can be integrated into the algorithm to further reduce the writes to Oâ€‹(n/Ï‰)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğœ”O(n/\sqrt{\omega}).

We begin by explaining sequential algorithms that we believe to be new and interesting. Then in SectionÂ 5.4 we show that these algorithms are parallelizable. For this section, we assume the size of the symmetric memory in our model is Oâ€‹(kâ€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜ğ‘›O(k\log n).

In this section we assume that the graph is connected. If not, we can run the connectivity algorithm and then run the algorithm on each component. The results for a graph are the union of the results of each of its connected components.

5.1 The Classic Algorithm

The classic parallel algorithmÂ [45] to compute biconnected components and bridges of a connected graph is based on the Euler-tour technique. The algorithm starts by building a spanning tree Tğ‘‡T rooted at some arbitrary vertex. Each vertex is labeled by firstâ€‹(v)firstğ‘£{\mbox{\emph{first}}}(v) and lastâ€‹(v)lastğ‘£{\mbox{\emph{last}}}(v), which are the ranks of vğ‘£vâ€™s first and last appearance on the Euler tour of Tğ‘‡T. The low value lowâ€‹(v)lowğ‘£{\mbox{\emph{low}}}(v) and the high value highâ€‹(v)highğ‘£{\mbox{\emph{high}}}(v) of a vertex vâˆˆVğ‘£ğ‘‰v\in V are defined as:

lowâ€‹(v)=minâ¡{wâ€‹(u)âˆ£uâ€‹ is in the subtree rooted at â€‹v}lowğ‘£conditionalğ‘¤ğ‘¢ğ‘¢ is in the subtree rooted at ğ‘£\displaystyle{\mbox{\emph{low}}}(v)=\min\{w(u)\mid u{\mbox{\emph{ is in the subtree rooted at }}}v\}
highâ€‹(v)=maxâ¡{wâ€‹(u)âˆ£uâ€‹ is in the subtree rooted at â€‹v}highğ‘£conditionalğ‘¤ğ‘¢ğ‘¢ is in the subtree rooted at ğ‘£\displaystyle{\mbox{\emph{high}}}(v)=\max\{w(u)\mid u{\mbox{\emph{ is in the subtree rooted at }}}v\}

where

wâ€‹(u)=minâ¡{firstâ€‹(u)âˆª{firstâ€‹(uâ€²)âˆ£(u,uâ€²)â€‹ is a nontree edge}}ğ‘¤ğ‘¢firstğ‘¢conditional-setfirstsuperscriptğ‘¢â€²ğ‘¢superscriptğ‘¢â€² is a nontree edgew(u)=\min\{{\mbox{\emph{first}}}(u)\cup\{{\mbox{\emph{first}}}(u^{\prime})\mid(u,u^{\prime}){\mbox{\emph{ is a nontree edge}}}\}\}

Namely, lowâ€‹(v)lowğ‘£{\mbox{\emph{low}}}(v) and highâ€‹(v)highğ‘£{\mbox{\emph{high}}}(v) indicate the first and last vertex on the Euler tour that are connected by a nontree edge to the subtree rooted at vğ‘£v. The lowâ€‹(â‹…)lowâ‹…{\mbox{\emph{low}}}(\cdot) and highâ€‹(â‹…)highâ‹…{\mbox{\emph{high}}}(\cdot) values can be computed by a reduce on each vertex followed by a leaffix444Leaffix is similar to prefix but defined on a tree and computed from the leaves to the root. on the subtrees. The computation takes Oâ€‹(Ï‰â€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğœ”ğ‘›O(\omega{}\log n) 0pt, Oâ€‹(m+Ï‰â€‹n)ğ‘‚ğ‘šğœ”ğ‘›O(m+\omega{}n) work, and Oâ€‹(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n) writes on the Asymmetric NPÂ model, by using the algorithm and scheduling theorem inÂ [9]. Then a tree edge is a bridge if and only if the childâ€™s low and high is inclusively within the range of first and last of the parent. This parallel algorithm is asymptotically optimal even sequentially without considering asymmetric read and write costs.

The standard output of biconnected componentsÂ [21, 32] is an array Bâ€‹[â‹…]ğµdelimited-[]â‹…B[\cdot] with size mğ‘šm, where the iğ‘–i-th element in BğµB indicates which biconnected component the iğ‘–i-th edge belongs to. Explicitly writing-out BğµB is costly in the asymmetric setting, especially when mâ‰«nmuch-greater-thanğ‘šğ‘›m\gg n. We provide an alternative BC labeling as output that only requires Oâ€‹(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n) writes.

5.2 The BC Labeling

Here we describe the BC (biconnected-component) labeling, which effectively represents biconnectivity output in Oâ€‹(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n) space. Instead of storing all edges within each biconnected component, the BC labeling stores a component label for each vertex, and a vertex for each component. An example of a BC labeling of a graph is shown in FigureÂ 2. We will later show how to use this representation along with an implicit decomposition to reduce the writes further.

Definition 3 (BC labeling).

The BC labeling of a connected graph with respect to a rooted spanning tree stores a vertex label l:V\{root}â†’[C]:ğ‘™â†’\ğ‘‰rootdelimited-[]ğ¶l:V\backslash\{\textit{root}\}\to[C] where Cğ¶C is the number of biconnected components in the graph, and a component head r:[C]â†’V:ğ‘Ÿâ†’delimited-[]ğ¶ğ‘‰r:[C]\to V of each biconnected component.

Lemma 5.1.

The BC labeling of a connected graph can be computed in Oâ€‹(m)ğ‘‚ğ‘šO(m) operations and Oâ€‹(n+m/Ï‰)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘šğœ”O(n+m/\omega) writes on the Asymmetric RAM. Queries about bridges, articulation points, or biconnected components can be answered in no writes and Oâ€‹(1)ğ‘‚1O(1) operations given a BC labeling on a rooted spanning tree.

The algorithm to compute BC labeling. A vertex vâˆˆVğ‘£ğ‘‰v\in V (except for the root) is an articulation point iff there exists at least one child uğ‘¢u in the spanning tree that has firstâ€‹(v)â‰¤lowâ€‹(u)firstğ‘£lowğ‘¢{\mbox{\emph{first}}}(v)\leq{\mbox{\emph{low}}}(u) and highâ€‹(u)â‰¤lastâ€‹(v)highğ‘¢lastğ‘£{\mbox{\emph{high}}}(u)\leq{\mbox{\emph{last}}}(v). We thus name the tree edge between such a pair of vertices to be a critical edge. The algorithm to compute the BC labeling simply removes all critical edges and runs graph connectivity on all remaining graph edges. Then the algorithm described in SectionÂ 4.2 gives a unique component label that we assign as the vertex label. For each component, its head is the vertex that is the parent of its cluster in the spanning tree. Each connected component and its head form a biconnected component.

The correctness of the algorithm can be proven by showing the equivalence of the result of this algorithm and that of the Tarjan-Vishkin algorithmÂ [45].

Since the number of biconnected components is at most nğ‘›n, the spanning tree, vertex labels, and component heads require only linear space. Therefore, the space requirement of the BC labeling is Oâ€‹(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n).

Query on BC labeling. We now show that queries are easy with the BC labeling. An edge is a bridge iff it is the only edge connecting a single-vertex component and its component head (the biconnected component contains this single edge). The root of the spanning tree is an articulation point iff it is the head of at least two biconnected components. Any other vertex is an articulation point iff it is the head of at least one biconnected component. A block-cut tree can also be generated from the BC labeling: for each vertex create an edge from itself and its vertex label; and for each component create an edge from the label of this component to the component head. We have a block-cut tree after removing degree-1 nodes corresponding to vertices.

This new representation can be interpreted as an implicit version of the standard outputÂ [21, 32] of biconnected components, i.e.Â the label of the biconnected component of each edge can be reported in Oâ€‹(1)ğ‘‚1O(1) operations. This is simple: we report the label of the endpoint of the edge that is further from the root along the spanning tree. The correctness can be shown in two cases: if the edge is a spanning tree edge, then the component label is stored in the further vertex; otherwise, the two vertices must have the same label and reporting either one gives the label of this biconnected component.


Using BC labeling gives the following theorem (see SectionÂ 5.4 for 0ptÂ analysis).

Theorem 5.2.

Articulation points, bridges, and biconnected components on the Asymmetric NPÂ model take Oâ€‹(m+nâ€‹Ï‰)ğ‘‚ğ‘šğ‘›ğœ”O(m+n\omega) expected work and Oâ€‹(Ï‰â€‹minâ¡{Ï‰,m/n}â€‹log2â¡n)ğ‘‚ğœ”ğœ”ğ‘šğ‘›superscript2ğ‘›O(\omega\min\{\omega,m/n\}\log^{2}n) 0ptÂ whp, and each query can be answered in Oâ€‹(1)ğ‘‚1O(1) work.

It is interesting to point out that the BC labeling can efficiently answer queries that are non-trivial when using the standard output. For example, consider the query: are two vertices in the same biconnected component? With the BC labeling we can answer the query by finding the label of the lower vertex and checking whether the higher one has the same label or is the component head of this component. To the best of our knowledge, answering such queries on the standard representation can be hard, unless other information is also kept (e.g.Â a block-cut tree).

5.3 Biconnectivity Oracle in Sublinear Writes

Next we will show how the implicit kğ‘˜k-decomposition generated by AlgorithmÂ 1 can be integrated into the algorithm to further reduce writes in the case of bounded-degree graphs. Our goal is as follows.

Theorem 5.3.

There exists an algorithm that computes articulation points, bridges, and biconnected components of a bounded-degree graph in Oâ€‹(nâ€‹Ï‰)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğœ”O(n\sqrt{\omega}) expected work, Oâ€‹(n/Ï‰)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğœ”O(n/\sqrt{\omega{}}) writes and Oâ€‹(Ï‰3/2â€‹log3â¡n)ğ‘‚superscriptğœ”32superscript3ğ‘›O(\omega^{3/2}\log^{3}n) 0pt, and each query takes an expected Oâ€‹(Ï‰)ğ‘‚ğœ”O(\omega{}) work and Oâ€‹(Ï‰â€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğœ”ğ‘›O(\omega{}\log n) work whp, with no writes, on the Asymmetric NPÂ model.

The overall idea of the new algorithm is to replace the vertices in the original graph with the clusters generated by AlgorithmÂ 1. We generate the BC labeling on the clusters graph (so the vertex labels are now the cluster labels), and then show that a connected-type query can be answered using only the information on the clusters graph and a constant number of associated clusters. The cost analysis is based on the parameter kğ‘˜k, and using k=Ï‰ğ‘˜ğœ”k=\sqrt{\omega{}} gives the result in the theorem.

The BC labeling on the clusters graph

In the first step of the algorithm we generate the BC labeling on the clusters graph with k=Ï‰ğ‘˜ğœ”k=\sqrt{\omega}. We root this spanning tree and name it the clusters spanning tree. The head vertex of a cluster is chosen as the cluster root for that cluster. (The root cluster does not have a cluster root.) For a cluster, we call the endpoint of a cluster tree edge outside of the cluster an outside vertex. The outside vertices of a cluster is the set of outside vertices of all associated cluster tree edges. Note that all outside vertices except for one are the cluster roots for neighbor clusters.

The local graph of a cluster

We next define the concept of the local graph of a cluster, so that each query only needs to look up a constant number of associated local graphs. An example of a local graph is shown in FigureÂ 3 and a more formal definition is as follows.

Definition 4 (local graph).

The local graph Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} of a cluster is defined as (ViâˆªVo,Eâ€²)subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘œsuperscriptğ¸â€²(V_{i}\cup V_{o},E^{\prime}). Visubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–V_{i} is the set of vertices in the cluster and Vosubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘œV_{o} is the set of outside vertices. Eâ€²superscriptğ¸â€²E^{\prime} consists of:

  1. 1.

    The edges with both endpoints in this cluster and the associated clustersâ€™ tree edges.

  2. 2.

    For cğ‘c neighbor clusters sharing the same cluster label, we find the cğ‘c corresponding outside vertices in Vosubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘œV_{o}, and connect the vertices with câˆ’1ğ‘1c-1 edges.

  3. 3.

    For an edge (v1,v2)subscriptğ‘£1subscriptğ‘£2(v_{1},v_{2}) with only one endpoint v1subscriptğ‘£1v_{1} in Visubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–V_{i}, we find the outside vertex vosubscriptğ‘£ğ‘œv_{o} that is connected to v2subscriptğ‘£2v_{2} on the cluster spanning tree, and create an edge from v1subscriptğ‘£1v_{1} to vosubscriptğ‘£ğ‘œv_{o}.

FigureÂ 3 shows an example local graph. Solid black lines are edges within the cluster and solid grey lines are cluster tree edges. Neighbor clusters that share a label are shown with dashed outlines and connected via curved dashed lines. e1subscriptğ‘’1e_{1} and e2subscriptğ‘’2e_{2} are examples of edges with only one endpoint in the cluster, and they are replaced by e1â€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘’1â€²e_{1}^{\prime} and e2â€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘’2â€²e_{2}^{\prime} respectively.

Computing local graphs requires a spanning tree and BC labeling of the clusters graph.

Lemma 5.4.

The cost to construct one local graph is Oâ€‹(k2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2O(k^{2}) in expectation and Oâ€‹(k2â€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2ğ‘›O(k^{2}\log n) whp on the Asymmetric RAM model.

Proof.

Each cluster in the implicit kğ‘˜k-decomposition has at most kğ‘˜k vertices, so finding the vertices Visubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–V_{i} takes Oâ€‹(câ€‹k)ğ‘‚ğ‘ğ‘˜O(ck) cost where cğ‘c is the cost to compute the mapping Ïâ€‹(â‹…)ğœŒâ‹…\rho(\cdot) of a vertex (Oâ€‹(k)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜O(k) in expectation and Oâ€‹(kâ€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜ğ‘›O(k\log n) whp). Since each vertex has a constant degree, there will be at most Oâ€‹(k)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜O(k) neighbor clusters, so |Vo|=Oâ€‹(k)subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘œğ‘‚ğ‘˜|V_{o}|=O(k). Enumerating and checking the other endpoint of the edges adjacent to Visubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–V_{i} takes Oâ€‹(câ€‹k)ğ‘‚ğ‘ğ‘˜O(ck) cost. Finding the new endpoint of an edge in category 3 requires constant cost after an Oâ€‹(n/k)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘˜O(n/k) preprocessing of the Euler tour of the cluster spanning tree. The number of neighbor clusters is Oâ€‹(k)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜O(k) so checking the cluster labels and adding edges costs no more than Oâ€‹(k)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜O(k). The overall cost to construct one local graph is thus Oâ€‹(k2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2O(k^{2}) in expectation and Oâ€‹(k2â€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2ğ‘›O(k^{2}\log n) whp. Since cğ‘c is Oâ€‹(k)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜O(k) in expectation and Oâ€‹(kâ€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜ğ‘›O(k\log n) whp, the overall cost matches the bounds in the lemma. âˆ

Queries

With the local graph and the BC labeling on the clusters graph, all sorts of biconnectivity queries can be made. Some of them are easier while other queries require more steps, and the preprocessing steps are shown in an overview of AlgorithmÂ 2.

Bridges. There are three cases when deciding whether an edge is a bridge: a tree edge in the clusters spanning tree, a cross edge in the clusters spanning tree, or an edge with both endpoints in the same cluster. Deciding which case to use takes constant operations.

A tree edge is a bridge if and only if it is a bridge of the clusters graph, which we can mark with Oâ€‹(n/k)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘˜O(n/k) writes while computing the BC labeling. A cross edge cannot be a bridge.

For an edge within a cluster, we use the following lemma:

Lemma 5.5.

An edge with both endpoints in one cluster is a bridge if and only if it is a bridge in the local graph of the the corresponding cluster.

Proof.

If an edge is a bridge in the original graph it means that there are no edges from the subtree of the lower vertex to the outside except for this edge itself. By applying the modifications of the edges, this property still holds, which means the edge is still a bridge in the local graph and vice versa. âˆ

Checking if an edge in a cluster is a bridge takes Oâ€‹(k2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2O(k^{2}) on average and Oâ€‹(k2â€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2ğ‘›O(k^{2}\log n) whp.

Articulation points. By a similar argument that a vertex is an articulation point of the original graph if and only if it is an articulation point of the associated local graph. Given a query vertex vğ‘£v, we can check whether it is an articulation point in local graph associated to vğ‘£v, which costs Oâ€‹(k2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2O(k^{2}) on average and Oâ€‹(k2â€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2ğ‘›O(k^{2}\log n) whp.


We now discuss how some more complex queries can be made. To start with, we show some definitions and results that are used in the algorithms for queries.

Definition 5 (root biconnectivity).

We say a vertex vğ‘£v in a cluster Cğ¶Câ€™s local graph is root-biconnected if vğ‘£v and the cluster root have the same vertex label in Cğ¶Câ€™s local graph.

A root-biconnected vertex vğ‘£v indicate that vğ‘£v can connect to the ancestor clusters without using the cluster root (i.e.Â the cluster root is not an articulation point to cut vğ‘£v). Another interpretation is that, there is no articulation point in cluster Cğ¶C that disconnects vğ‘£v from the outside vertex of the cluster root.

Lemma 5.6.

Computing and storing the root biconnectivity of all outside vertices in all local graphs takes Oâ€‹(nâ€‹k)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘˜O(nk) operations in expectation and Oâ€‹(n/k)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘˜O(n/k) writes on the Asymmetric RAM.

The proof is straight-forward. The cost to construct the local graphs and compute root biconnectivity is Oâ€‹(nâ€‹k)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘˜O(nk), and since there are Oâ€‹(n/k)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘˜O(n/k) clusters tree edges, storing the results requires Oâ€‹(n/k)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘˜O(n/k) writes.

Querying whether two vertices are biconnected. Checking whether two vertices v1subscriptğ‘£1v_{1} and v2subscriptğ‘£2v_{2} can be disconnected by removing any single vertex in the graph is one of the most commonly-used biconnectivity-style queries. To answer this query, our goal is to find the tree path between this pair of vertices and check whether there is an articulation point on this path that disconnects them.

The simple case is when v1subscriptğ‘£1v_{1} and v2subscriptğ‘£2v_{2} are within the same cluster. We know that the two vertices are connected by a path via the vertices within the cluster. We can check whether any vertex on the path disconnects these two vertices using their vertex labels.

Otherwise, v1subscriptğ‘£1v_{1} and v2subscriptğ‘£2v_{2} are in different clusters C1subscriptğ¶1C_{1} and C2subscriptğ¶2C_{2}. Assume CLCAsubscriptğ¶LCAC_{{\mbox{\scriptsize\emph{LCA}}}} is the cluster that contains the LCA of v1subscriptğ‘£1v_{1} and v2subscriptğ‘£2v_{2} (which can be computed by the LCA of C1subscriptğ¶1C_{1} and C2subscriptğ¶2C_{2} with constant cost) and vLCAâˆˆCLCAsubscriptğ‘£LCAsubscriptğ¶LCAv_{{\mbox{\scriptsize\emph{LCA}}}}\in C_{{\mbox{\scriptsize\emph{LCA}}}} is the LCA vertex. The tree path between v1subscriptğ‘£1v_{1} and v2subscriptğ‘£2v_{2} is from v1subscriptğ‘£1v_{1} to C1subscriptğ¶1C_{1}â€™s cluster root, and then to the cluster root of the outside vertex of C1subscriptğ¶1C_{1}â€™s cluster root, and so on, until reaching vLCAsubscriptğ‘£LCAv_{{\mbox{\scriptsize\emph{LCA}}}}, and the other half of the path can be constructed symmetrically. It takes Oâ€‹(k2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2O(k^{2}) expected cost to check whether any articulation point disconnects the paths in C1subscriptğ¶1C_{1}, C2subscriptğ¶2C_{2} and CLCAsubscriptğ¶LCAC_{{\mbox{\scriptsize\emph{LCA}}}}. For the rest of the clusters, since we have already precomputed and stored the root biconnectivity of all outside vertices, then applying a leafix on the clusters spanning tree computes the cluster containing the articulation point of each cluster root. Therefore checking whether such an articulation point on the path between C1subscriptğ¶1C_{1} and CLCAsubscriptğ¶LCAC_{{\mbox{\scriptsize\emph{LCA}}}} or between C2subscriptğ¶2C_{2} and CLCAsubscriptğ¶LCAC_{{\mbox{\scriptsize\emph{LCA}}}} that disconnects v1subscriptğ‘£1v_{1} and v2subscriptğ‘£2v_{2} takes Oâ€‹(1)ğ‘‚1O(1) cost. Therefore checking whether two vertices are biconnected requires Oâ€‹(k2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2O(k^{2}) cost in expectation and no writes.

Querying whether two vertices are 1-edge connected. This is a similar query comparing to the previous one and the only difference is whether an edge, instead of a vertex, is able to disconnect two vertices. The query can be answered in a similar way by checking whether a bridge disconnects the two vertices on their spanning tree path, which is related to the two clusters containing the two query vertices and the LCA cluster, and the precomputed information for the clusters on the tree path among these three clusters. The cost for a query is also Oâ€‹(k2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2O(k^{2}) operations in expectation and it requires no writes.

Queries on biconnected-component labels for edges. We now answer the standard queriesÂ [21, 32] of biconnected components: given an edge, report a unique label that represents the biconnected component this edge belongs to.

We have already described the algorithm to check whether any two vertices are biconnected, so the next step is to assign a unique label of each biconnected components, which requires the following lemma:

Lemma 5.7.

A vertex in one cluster is either in a biconnected component that only contains vertices in this cluster, or biconnected with at least one outside vertex of this cluster.

Proof.

Assume a vertex v1subscriptğ‘£1v_{1} in this cluster Cğ¶C is biconnected to another vertex v2subscriptğ‘£2v_{2} outside the cluster, then let vosubscriptğ‘£ğ‘œv_{o} be the outside vertex of Cğ¶C on the spanning tree path between v1subscriptğ‘£1v_{1} and v2subscriptğ‘£2v_{2}, and v1subscriptğ‘£1v_{1} is biconnected with vosubscriptğ‘£ğ‘œv_{o}, which proves the lemma. âˆ

With this lemma, we first compute and store the labels of the biconnected components on the cluster roots, which can be finished with Oâ€‹(nâ€‹k)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘˜O(nk) expected operations and Oâ€‹(n/k)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘˜O(n/k) writes with the BC labeling on the clusters graph and the the root biconnectivity of outside vertices on all clusters. Then for each cluster we count the number of biconnected components completely within this cluster. Finally we apply a prefix sum on the numbers for the clusters to provide a unique label of each biconnected component in every cluster. Although not explicitly stored, the vertex labels in each cluster can be regenerated with Oâ€‹(k2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2O(k^{2}) operations in expectation and Oâ€‹(k2â€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2ğ‘›O(k^{2}\log n) operations whp, and a vertex label is either the same as that of an outside vertex which is precomputed, or a relative label within the cluster plus the offset of this cluster.

Similar to the algorithm discussed in SectionÂ 5.2, when a query comes, the edge can either be a cluster tree edge, a cross edge, or within a cluster. For the first case the label biconnected component is the precomputed label for the (lower) cluster root. For the second case we just report the vertex label of an arbitrary endpoint, and similarly for the third case the output is the vertex label of the lower vertex in the cluster. The cost of a query is Oâ€‹(k2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2O(k^{2}) in expectation and Oâ€‹(k2â€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2ğ‘›O(k^{2}\log n) whp.


With the concepts and lemmas in this section, with a precomputation of Oâ€‹(nâ€‹k)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘˜O(nk) cost and Oâ€‹(n/k)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘˜O(n/k) writes, we can also do a normal query with Oâ€‹(k2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2O(k^{2}) cost in expectation and Oâ€‹(k2â€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2ğ‘›O(k^{2}\log n) whp on bridge-block tree, cut-block tree, and 1-edge-connected components.

5.4 Parallelizing Biconnectivity Algorithms

The two biconnectivity algorithms discussed in this section are essentially highly parallelizable. The key algorithmic components include Euler-tour construction, tree contraction, graph connectivity, prefix sum, and preprocessing LCA queries on the spanning tree. Since the algorithms run each of the components a constant number of times, and the 0pt of the algorithm is bounded by the 0pt of graph connectivity, whose bound is provided in SectionÂ 4 (Oâ€‹(Ï‰2â€‹log2â¡n)ğ‘‚superscriptğœ”2superscript2ğ‘›O(\omega^{2}\log^{2}n) and Oâ€‹(Ï‰3/2â€‹log3â¡n)ğ‘‚superscriptğœ”32superscript3ğ‘›O(\omega^{3/2}\log^{3}n) whp respectively when plugging in Î²ğ›½\beta as 1/Ï‰1ğœ”1/\omega{} and 1/Ï‰1ğœ”1/\sqrt{\omega}{}).555The classic parallel algorithms with polylogarithmic depth solve the Euler-tour construction, tree contraction, and prefix sum, since we here only require linear writes (in terms of number of vertices, Oâ€‹(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n) and Oâ€‹(n/k)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘˜O(n/k) for the two algorithms) for both algorithms.

For the sublinear-write algorithm, we assume that computations within a cluster are sequential, and the work is upper bounded by Oâ€‹(k2)=Oâ€‹(Ï‰)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2ğ‘‚ğœ”O(k^{2})=O(\omega{}) in expectation and Oâ€‹(k2â€‹logâ¡n)=Oâ€‹(Ï‰â€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘˜2ğ‘›ğ‘‚ğœ”ğ‘›O(k^{2}\log n)=O(\omega{}\log n) whp for any computations within a cluster. This term is additive to the overall depth, since after acquiring the spanning tree (forest) of the clusters, we run all computations within the clusters in parallel and then run tree contraction and prefix sums based on the calculated values. The Oâ€‹(Ï‰)ğ‘‚ğœ”O(\omega{}) expected work (Oâ€‹(Ï‰â€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğœ”ğ‘›O(\omega{}\log n) whp) is also the cost for a single biconnectivity query, and multiple queries can be done in parallel.

6 Sublinear-Write Algorithms on Unbounded-Degree Graphs

Here we discuss a solution to generate another graph Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} which has bounded degree with Oâ€‹(m)ğ‘‚ğ‘šO(m) vertices and edges, and the connectivity queries on the original graph GğºG can be answered in Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} equivalently.

The overall idea is to build a tree structure with virtual nodes for each vertex that has more than a constant degree. Each virtual node will represent a certain range of the edge list. Considering a star with all other vertices connecting to a specific vertex v1subscriptğ‘£1v_{1}, we build a binary tree structure with 2 virtual nodes on the first level v1,2â†’n/2subscriptğ‘£â†’12ğ‘›2v_{1,2\to n/2}, v1,n/2+1â†’nsubscriptğ‘£â†’1ğ‘›21ğ‘›v_{1,n/2+1\to n}, 4 virtual nodes on the second level v1,2â†’n/4,â‹¯,v1,3â€‹n/4+1â†’nsubscriptğ‘£â†’12ğ‘›4â‹¯subscriptğ‘£â†’13ğ‘›41ğ‘›v_{1,2\to n/4},\cdots,v_{1,3n/4+1\to n} and so on. We replace the endpoint of an edge from the original graph GğºG with the leaf node in this tree structure that represents the corresponding range with a constant number of edges. Notice that if both endpoints of an edge have large degrees, then they both have to be redirected.

The simple case is for a sparse graph in which most of the vertices are bounded-degree, and the sum of the degrees for vertices with more than a constant number of edges is Oâ€‹(n/k)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘˜O(n/k) (or Oâ€‹(n/Ï‰)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğœ”O(n/\sqrt{\omega})). In this case we can simply explicitly build a tree structure for the edges of a vertex.

Otherwise, we require the adjacency array of the input graph to have the following property: each edge can query its positions in the edge lists for both endpoints. Namely, an edge (u,v)ğ‘¢ğ‘£(u,v) knows it is the iğ‘–i-th edge in uğ‘¢uâ€™s edge list and jğ‘—j-th edge in vğ‘£vâ€™s edge list. To achieve this, either an extra pointer is stored for each edge, or the edge lists are presorted and the label can be binary searched (this requires Oâ€‹(logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(\log n) work for each edge lookup). With this information, there exists an implicit graph Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} with bounded-degree. The binary tree structures can be defined such that given an internal tree node, we can find the three neighbors (two neighbors for the root) without explicitly storing the newly added vertices and edges. Notice that the new graph Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} now has Oâ€‹(m)ğ‘‚ğ‘šO(m) vertices including the virtual ones. The virtual nodes help to generate implicit kğ‘˜k-decomposition and require no writes unless they are selected to be either primary or secondary centers.

Graph connectivity is obviously not affected by this transformation. It is easy to check that a bridge in the original graph GğºG is also a bridge in the new graph Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} and vice versa. In the biconnectivity algorithm, an edge in GğºG can be split into multiple edges in Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}, but this will not change the biconnectivity property within a biconnected component, unless the component only contains one bridge edge, which can be checked separately.

This construction, combined with our earlier results, leads to TheoremÂ 1.2.

7 Conclusion

This work provides several algorithms targeted at solving graph connectivity problems considering the read-write asymmetry. Our algorithms make use of an implicit decomposition technique that is applicable beyond the scope of the problems studied in this paper. By using this decomposition and redundantly performing small computation, we are able to reduce the number of writes in exchange for a small increase in the total number of operations. This allows us to offset the increased cost of writes in anticipated future systems and improve overall performance. Even excluding new memory technology, we believe that research into algorithms with fewer writes provides interesting results from both a theoretical and memory/cache coherence perspective. Our work provides a framework which can be used to develop write-efficient solutions to large graph connectivity problems.

Appendix A Motivation fromÂ [12]

Further motivation for the asymmetry between reads and write costs in emerging memory technologies was provided inÂ [12]. As a convenience to the reviewer, in this appendix we repeat a suitable excerpt from that paper.

â€œWhile DRAM stores data in capacitors that typically require refreshing every few milliseconds, and hence must be continuously powered, emerging NVM technologies store data as â€œstatesâ€ of the given material that require no external power to retain. Energy is required only to read the cell or change its value (i.e., its state). While there is no significant cost difference between reading and writing DRAM (each DRAM read of a location not currently buffered requires a write of the DRAM row being evicted, and hence is also a write), emerging NVMs such as Phase-Change Memory (PCM), Spin-Torque Transfer Magnetic RAM (STT-RAM), and Memristor-based Resistive RAM (ReRAM) each incur significantly higher cost for writing than reading. This large gap seems fundamental to the technologies themselves: to change the physical state of a material requires relatively significant energy for a sufficient duration, whereas reading the current state can be done quickly and, to ensure the state is left unchanged, with low energy. An STT-RAM cell, for example, can be read in 0.14 nâ€‹sğ‘›ğ‘ ns but uses a 10 nâ€‹sğ‘›ğ‘ ns writing pulse duration, using roughly 10âˆ’15superscript101510^{-15} joules to read versus 10âˆ’12superscript101210^{-12} joules to writeÂ [23] (these are the raw numbers at the materials level). A Memristor ReRAM cell uses a 100 nâ€‹sğ‘›ğ‘ ns write pulse duration, and an 8MB Memrister ReRAM chip is projected to have reads with 1.7 nâ€‹sğ‘›ğ‘ ns latency and 0.2 nâ€‹Jğ‘›ğ½nJ energy versus writes with 200 nâ€‹sğ‘›ğ‘ ns latency and 25 nâ€‹Jğ‘›ğ½nJ energyÂ [49]â€”over two orders of magnitude differences in latency and energy. PCM is the most mature of the three technologies, and early generations are already available as I/O devices. A recent paperÂ [33] reported 6.7 Î¼â€‹sğœ‡ğ‘ \mu s latency for a 4KB read and 128 Î¼â€‹sğœ‡ğ‘ \mu s latency for a 4KB write. Another reported that the sector I/O latency and bandwidth for random 512B writes was a factor of 15 worse than for readsÂ [30]. As a future memory/cache replacement, a 512Mb PCM memory chip is projected to have 16 nâ€‹sğ‘›ğ‘ ns byte reads versus 416 nâ€‹sğ‘›ğ‘ ns byte writes, and writes to a 16MB PCM L3 cache are projected to be up to 40 times slower and use 17 times more energy than readsÂ [22]. While these numbers are speculative and subject to change as the new technologies emerge over time, there seems to be sufficient evidence that writes will be considerably more costly than reads in these NVMs.â€

Note that, unlike SSDs and earlier versions of phase-change memory products, these emerging memory products will sit on the processorâ€™s memory bus and be accessed at byte granularity via loads and stores (like DRAM). Thus, the time and energy for reading can be roughly on par with DRAM, and depends primarily on the properties of the technology itself relative to DRAM.

Appendix B Formal Definitions of the Terms

A spanning tree Tğ‘‡T of an undirected connected graph GğºG is a subgraph that is a tree which includes all of the vertices of GğºG. A spanning forest of GğºG contains the union of the spanning trees of all connected components in GğºG. The lowest-common-ancestor (LCA) query for two vertices on a rooted spanning tree requires Oâ€‹(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n) work and Oâ€‹(logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(\log n) depth on preprocessing, and Oâ€‹(1)ğ‘‚1O(1) query timeÂ [11, 42].

A connected component of GğºG is a subgraph in which any two vertices are connected to each other by paths via edges in the graph.

A biconnected component (also known as a block or 2-connected component) of GğºG is a maximal subgraph such that it is still connected after removing any single vertex in the subgraph. Any connected graph decomposes into a tree of biconnected components called the block-cut tree of the graph. The blocks are attached to each other at shared vertices called articulation points.

A bridge of GğºG is an edge whose deletion increases the number of connected components of the graph. A connected graph is kğ‘˜k-edge-connected if it remains connected whenever fewer than kğ‘˜k edges are removed. An unconnected graph is 0-edge connected; a connected graph with bridges is 1-edge-connected; and a bridge-less graph is at least 2-edge-connected.

Appendix C Summary of Low-Diameter Decomposition Algorithm

The algorithm of Miller et al.Â [36] generates a (Î²,Oâ€‹(logâ¡n/Î²))ğ›½ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ›½(\beta,O({\log n}/\beta)) decomposition with Oâ€‹(m)ğ‘‚ğ‘šO(m) operations and Oâ€‹(Ï‰â€‹log2â¡n/Î²)ğ‘‚ğœ”superscript2ğ‘›ğ›½O(\omega{\log^{2}n}/\beta) 0ptÂ whp. As described by Miller et al., the number of writes performed is also Oâ€‹(m)ğ‘‚ğ‘šO(m), but this can be improved to Oâ€‹(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n). Specifically, the algorithm executes multiple breadth-first searches (BFSâ€™s) in parallel, which can be replaced by write-efficient BFSâ€™s.

In more detail, the algorithm first assigns each vertex vğ‘£v a value Î´vsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘£\delta_{v} drawn from an exponential distribution with parameter Î²ğ›½\beta (mean 1/Î²1ğ›½1/\beta). Then on iteration iğ‘–i of the algorithm, BFSâ€™s are started from unexplored vertices vğ‘£v where Î´vâˆˆ[i,i+1)subscriptğ›¿ğ‘£ğ‘–ğ‘–1\delta_{v}\in[i,i+1) and all BFSâ€™s that have already started are advanced one level. At the end of the algorithm, all vertices that were visited by a BFS starting from the same source will belong to the same subset of the decomposition. If a vertex is visited by multiple BFSâ€™s in the same iteration, it can be assigned to an arbitrary BFS.666The original analysis of Miller et al.Â [36] requires the vertex to be assigned to the BFS with the smaller fractional part of Î´ssubscriptğ›¿ğ‘ \delta_{s}, where sğ‘ s is the source of the BFS. However, Shun et al.Â [43] show that an arbitrary assignment gives the same complexity bounds. The maximum value of Î´vsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘£\delta_{v} can be shown to be Oâ€‹(logâ¡n/Î²)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ›½O({\log n}/\beta) whp, and so the algorithm terminates in Oâ€‹(logâ¡n/Î²)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ›½O(\log n/\beta) iterations. Each iteration requires Oâ€‹(Ï‰â€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğœ”ğ‘›O(\omega\log n) 0ptÂ for packing the frontiers of the BFSâ€™s, leading to an overall 0ptÂ of Oâ€‹(Ï‰â€‹log2â¡n/Î²)ğ‘‚ğœ”superscript2ğ‘›ğ›½O(\omega\log^{2}n/\beta) whp. A standard BFS requires operations and writes that are linear in the number of vertices and edges explored, giving a total work of Oâ€‹(Ï‰â€‹(m+n))ğ‘‚ğœ”ğ‘šğ‘›O(\omega(m+n)). By using the write-efficient BFS fromÂ [9], the expected number of writes for each BFS is proportional to the number of vertices marked (assigned to it), and so the total expected number of writes is Oâ€‹(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n). Tasks only need Oâ€‹(1)ğ‘‚1O(1) symmetric memory in the algorithm. This yields TheoremÂ 4.1.
